repnme.cdata!:
Cote d'Ivoire - Fifth Oil Palm
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fifth Oil Palm
            Development Project for Cote d'Ivoire was
            unsatisfactory. The project failed to achieve its
            objectives, institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is unlikely, and the performance of the Bank
            was satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, support prices for producers during an
            extended period of low market external prices for a
            commodity, coupled with an over-valued currency, are
            non-sustainable, even by the healthiest of economies and can
            have devastating consequences for agencies responsible for
            bearing the cost of such support. Second, the sustainability
            of a government commercial organization is closely linked to
            a favorable economic framework, appropriate pricing
            policies, and the availability of strong managerial and
            financial skills related to the size of its operations.
            Third, technical assistance personnel in charge of
            implementing project activities are seldom able to devote
            time to building local capacity or be advocates of major
            restructuring of the operation they manage. Finally, if no
            clear distinction is made between the social and
            profit-oriented operations through government budgets,
            supporting social activities from profits can soon become untenable.

repnme.cdata!: Ivory Coast - Fifth Oil Palm Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Oil Palm Development Project
            will (i) help the Ivory Coast meet an increasing demand for
            fats and edible oils through both replacement of existing
            aging oil palm plantings and development of new plantings in
            selected areas; (ii) further diversify and strengthen the
            Ivory Coast agricultural sector through investment in a crop
            with substantial comparative advantages and good long-term
            growth prospects; (iii) assist in maintenance of a tree
            cover in an area where the forest cover is being depleted
            rapidly. The project will consist of the following
            components: (a) establishment of 11,600 ha of new
            PALMINDUSTRIE industrial oil palm plantations and replanting
            of about 15,000 ha of aging plantations; (b) development of
            smallholder oil palm plantings through expansion and
            replanting of existing areas by about 29,100 ha and new
            planting of 6,900 ha; (c) establishment of a pilot scheme of
            2,100 ha medium-sized private oil palm plantations; (d)
            construction of two oil mills for PALMINDUSTRIE with
            eventual capacities each of 40 tons FFB/hour; (e) a study of
            effluent treatment systems and installation of an effluent
            treatment prototype system at an existing PALMINDUSTRIE oil
            mill and an effluent prototype digestor at Ehania; (f)
            support of accompanying research; (g) technical assistance
            to PALMINDUSTRIE.
